snippet: Adm. William H. McRaven, who led the mission to kill Osama bin Laden, aims to recast the Special Operations forces to face a widening array of new threats as America’s combat role in the Middle East winds down.
abstract: Adm William H McRaven, who assumed command of America's Special Operations after leading mission to kill Osama bin Laden, is working to expand role of force beyond commando missions to encompass range of activities short of combat; his efforts have earned high-level support from officials eager to avoid large-scale foreign interventions, but some critics accuse him of overreaching or treading on traditional military turf.

byline.original: By ERIC SCHMITT and THOM SHANKER

lead_paragraph: Adm. William H. McRaven, who led the mission to kill Osama bin Laden, aims to recast the Special Operations forces to face a widening array of new threats as America’s combat role in the Middle East winds down.

headline.seo: Admiral McRaven Charts a New Path for Special Operations Command
headline.main: A Commander Seeks to Chart a New Path for Special Operations
headline.print_headline: A Commander Seeks To Chart a New Path For Special Operations

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject
